content: @bstrie Personally, I don't understand why Zulip would be preferable to GitHub issues for hosting long discussions. The major complaint I've seen about GitHub is that it's hard for someone to jump in and review the previous discussion, due to large volumes of text (plus the GitHub-specific issue where it tends to hide posts). But in that respect, surely something like Zulip, where, due to its focus on real-time communication, people tend to write significantly larger amounts of text – with lower information density and less time spent reviewing the text for accuracy/relevance before sending it – is even worse. I don't want to get into a long argument or anything (there is enough heat and noise in the strict_provenance discussion without meta discussions). But I'm legitimately puzzled why people prefer Zulip...
github issues is the worst discussion platform since twitter. it's completely impenetrable for branching technical conversations. zulip makes things tractable
True, Zulip's branching conversations feature is quite nice.

it's also easier to actually interact with other people on zulip because zulip comments feel like less effort, so to me it tends to feel less likely to get adversarial or cause people to talk past each other
there's also a lower bar to posting "stupid questions" because its more chat like
in addition, when using zulip it feels more important to actually summarize discussions, because the actual discussion is less dense
if we want to collect all the strict-provenance discussions into a single place for reference we can make a sub-channel of this one
Okay, those are good points.

while e.g. the unsafe-code-guidelines github repo to my knowledge doesn't summarize the current state of discussions which means i sometimes have to read 50 comments to figure out what is happening, continuously discarding outdated information
so yeah, imo zulip + summarize is better than github + no summarize and if we're summarizing anyways, then zulip is just a better platform for chatting

FWIW, I think this particular case is an instance where nothing would make reviewing this discussion tractable (other than summaries), but Zulip makes it easier than GitHub for a variety of reasons. It's still a massive undertaking either way.
I always have a hope that some day I (or someone else) could be paid to be a professional summarizer. It would be so useful.
I guess it would be like having our own LWN in a way.
yes, I envy linux for having LWN. TWiR is great for overviews, but LWN also does accessible deep dives
theoretically the inside rust blog can fill this role, but relies on people finding the time to contribute

finding the time to contribute

Thus the "someone could be paid" part — much easier to find the time then :wink:

@RalfJ FWIW, I have a significant amount of capacity to read more of what you have to say, especially given that it's likely that doing so will reduce the amount of time I (and hopefully you too) spend arguing in this stream. Of course I know that you're a busy person and that we're probably doing more than enough to exhaust your capacity for teaching the rest of us as is, and I don't mean to assign you more work by any means. At the same time though, if you ever get an urge to just write down all your thoughts about an idea in a hackmd, I want to encourage you to share such things, even if you don't necessarily think it'll be particularly coherent or you won't have time to answer follow up questions
